IMPERIAL FEDERATION

It is contended by the advocates of Imperial Federation that such an arrangement would solve the difficulties of the present situation and give a national strength to the Empire as a whole. But Imperial Federation would also mean the separation of the various provinces from each other, and the question naturally suggests itself to every Canadian—Would the provinces be able to do without such an arrangement as they would be subjected to? Would the provinces be able to take an interest in any movement having for its end the furthering of the interests of the Empire? Would we be able to separate ourselves from the rest of the Empire? Would we be able to maintain our independence?

THE INTER-PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE

Remarking on the recent inter-provincial conference the Globe says:—It has been frequently asserted by Sir John Macdonald's admirers that he proved himself to be a great statesman by bringing the Provinces together and creating a Canadian national spirit. This should have been accomplished by the Dominion Parliament, but as we are not fitted to do so, it seems to me we are quite proper to seek an opportunity of doing it. Mr. Davis' knowledge of North-west affairs, however, should be a guarantee that his bill will be equal to our requirements. It is found out now that the rights of the people of the North-west, or any section of it, are likely to be sacrificed, we shall not fail to oppose it.

The time has come when the government must have the fees under the Torrens System in the North-west reduced. So far, the people of this district have not been able to take advantage of the system. The regulations as to the age required to prove title are not practical to state what the public opinion of this District is as to the fees.

In an interview with Messrs. Davin and Perley the Minister of the Interior spoke of the plan of allowing a second homestead for pre-emption was out of the question, but that the Government would grant second homesteads to those entitled thereupon the 1st of June, 1887, whether they be of the first or second class. This should be an encouragement to settlers, if a second homestead is worth anything.

We learn by our dispatches also that the Government are considering the granting of pensions to the Mounted Police after a certain term of service. Had pensions been granted before it would have been the means of keeping many good men in the force and keeping it in a higher state of efficiency. The police are as much entitled to pension as the soldiers, and we trust that the Government will pass the measure referred to this session.

The agitation in Manitoba against disallowance in Manitoba still goes on with unabated vigor, and the Manitoba members have not been able to make any impression on the Government in the way of securing the desired concession. Two charters have been granted by the Manitoba Legislative Assembly, and the promoters of them propose to go on with their construction whether their charters are dissolved or not. This will, we fancy, have the effect of bringing things to a head and deciding the question one way or the other.

SPRING OPERATIONS

Farming operations commenced about the middle of last month, and the crops being planted, farmers were busy. Those who prepared their land last fall are well advanced with their seeding, while those who did not prepare their land last fall are, as a consequence, not so far advanced as they otherwise would have been. The spring this year is not expected to exceed last year's. Up to the present wheat is the principal crop, and the prices are high, with some exceptions, left for sale in a few days, however, the coarse grains will sell well, while the prices of potatoes and other vegetables will be governed by the season. The season, it is true, has not been a little hard, but though the crops are not large, we have hoped of raising a good crop, and gardening operations have just commenced.

CATTLE RAISING

The advantages this country possesses for the raising and wintering of cattle has been amply demonstrated by the experience of the last few years. Mr. Macdonald, however, has been unable to convince the farmers of the advantages of cattle raising. The cattle raised here are of a better quality than those raised elsewhere, and the cattle raised here are of a better quality than those raised elsewhere.

EDITORIAL NOTES

Sir John Macdonald will visit the North-west after the session ends.

The Globe of the 5th inst. says:—In describing the proceedings of a meeting of the friends of Sir Macdonald at the home of Mr. Macdonald, the Prince Albert Times says:—Chairs were taken by Mr. Macdonald, Sir John Macdonald, the Mayor, and the Government officials. This is true as far as I know, but why leave out Mr. Macdonald, Mr. Campbell, Mr. Macdonald, Sir John and the Queen.

From the report of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs we learn that the Indians of the North-west, including those of Manitoba and the North-west have 30,500. The expenditure on these Indians in 1886 was $1,094,188, showing an increase of $86,725 over the preceding year, or just over 9 per cent.

The approximate quantity of land held by the Government in trust for the Indians is given as 3,000,000 acres. The encouraging feature in this report is the increase, instead of decrease, in the expenditure.

The Globe of the 5th inst. says:—As it would seem to indicate a retrograde progress on their part in the acquirement of the art of making their own living.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, March 26th.

Weather fine, but spring is more lack-
ing than has been the case for several
years.

No prospect of a freshet this spring
and scarcity of melty road, the snow
is going away quickly.

Lumbermen have an order for
370,000 feet of lumber for Prince Ross,
Burlington, to be shipped first thing in
the morning.

J. Fraser left for the landing on Tues-
day to build two York boats for Colin
White who is going up to Edmonton to
sell the lumber. He will accompany Mr. Fraser. They will leave
early in May.

J. Hume is working at placer mining
near his quartz claims, out on the south
side of the river. A few feet above high
water mark there is a large deposit of
sandstone about 100 feet in length along
the bank of the river, resting on
white rock bedrock. Inside this bank Mr.
Hume has located a number of separate
feet, the dirt taken out averaging a con-
siderable amount of gold in the pan and getting better at each
working.

The Mining Department is taking
steps to experiment on the propagation
of willow in this part of the country.
Willow trees are being planted along
the banks of the river near the mouth
of the Lahontan, directly by the gravel
and indirectly by the larger numbers of
willow roots which have been
transported by this river. Willows will
probably be placed in the best situation
to plant to the best advantage
this spring and will be planted
next summer. Several operations
in town have also promised some
better results than was anticipated
here, with view to attracting more
business.

The experiment is well worth, but as
far as the question of willow propagation
is concerned, there is no one who
themselves in the matter have any prac-
tical knowledge of the rise or growth
thereby. They are not familiar with
Plants familiar in any degree with the
growth of willow and would confer a favor
by calling at the Bulletin office to be in-
terviewed on the subject.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Head of April 2.

Prince Roulston is removing their
small boat from the opposite side to the land
of the Saskatchewan.

Supt. Gagnon arrived by the last mail
and will take command of this post dur-
ing the absence of Supt. Gordon, who
was sent on leave in a few days.

John Daniels, arrested last week on
suspicion of having stolen the horse
of another man, was brought before the
court on Wednesday, there being no evidence
to criminate him.

Rev. J. C. Gardner, who has now
accepted the place of the Presbyterian Church of this place for the
past year, will preach tomorrow between noon and 2 o'clock. It has not yet been
decided who will succeed him.

A special stage arrived from Swift
Current yesterday afternoon, bringing
Mr. Thomas Dawes back to his family. He
left another brother at Swift Current to
change horses and was not expected to
be detained until the mails clear up.

There was good deal of discussion and
argument last year as to what was the
best method of disposing of pigeons. Pigeon
was generally accepted as the simplest
and most effective method of killing them,
but there was considerable room for
accomplishment, which would tend to
keep them in check, and that is to dis-
cover the best method of disposing of
young ones and hawks. Both these birds
prey largely on gophers and other vermin
in the fields.

W. Lottman's farm house near Edmon-
ton was burned on Wednesday, with
loss of property. Mrs. Lottman was
saved and tried to extinguish the fire which
caught from the chimney, using only
one cartridge which was in the house
before she left off for church. The fire
was compelled to give up without saving
anything.

LOCAL NEWS.

Archbishop Prinkham, Bishop desig-
nate of Saskatchewan, arrived last even-
ing and is stopping at the Queen's. He
was six days on the road from Qu'Appelle.

The ice in the Saskatchewan is slow to
move this year. It has probably got an
idea that it ought to be kept there until
the end of summer. We believe, however,
that the election is over. Go east, go
down the rapids as fast as you can.

We have received the report of the
election meeting held at Morden, Mani-
toba. It is a neatly printed and well
edited thirty-six column paper, and we
are happy to see such a strong side of
politics. We wish it success.

Wm. Plaxton, President of the Lorne
Agricultural Society, lately returned
from his handsomely furnished from the Co-
lonial Exhibition, awarded for a half-
bushel of White Russian wheat. The
medal was directed to A. H. Clark, Esq.,
Secretary of the Lorne Agricultural So-
ciety.

In the bowling tournament commenced
on Saturday night in the City Hall, Mr.
J. Hodgson, with a score of 291, D. Williamson,
second, 229; J. Knowles,
third, 213; C. Nairn, fourth. The
score is fair and the prizes are expected to see
the season broken before the 12th May, when
the tournament will be resumed.

We understand that the demand for
seed grain is greater than the supply.
We also understand that many who have
made up their minds to grow grain and
are located on the east side of the South
Branch, cannot get their seed until it
arrives, though a large quantity of
seed grain is now being shipped locally
owing to the farmers being unable to
cross the Branch. The Department, it seems to us,
would do well in making some arrangement to meet the emergency.

We clip the following interesting para-
graph from the Ottawa Journal, Canada:
"During the past few days the citizens were very much interested on
Tuesday evening at the marriage of Miss Mary Ann McTaggart, daughter of Mr.
McTaggart, formerly of this place, but now of Prince Albert, N.W.T., to Mr.
H. J. MacKenzie, of Prince Albert, N.W.T.

The marriage service was performed at 10:30 p.m., in the Presbyterian Church, by Rev. Mr. B. McLean, the
principal guest being from England. It is not
necessary to say that the bride looked charmingly. She was accompanied by
Miss Mary Ann Wilson, Miss Mary Ann
Kendall, her cousins, and the groom by
Mr. Ross MacKenzie. After the cere-
mony, they proceeded to the home of Mr. Wm. MacKenzie, uncle of the
bride, and partook of the bounteous re-
ception prepared for them. They left early
in the afternoon for a trip east before re-
turning to their future home in Prince
Albert, N.W.T."

QUEEN'S JUBILEE.

A public meeting took place on Wed-
nesday evening in the schoolrooms for
the purpose of taking the first step to
celebrate the Queen's Jubilee, Mayor
MacArthur presiding. After some dis-
cussion, it was decided that the celebra-
tion take place on Dominion Day, and
that a general committee be appointed
with instructions to arrange a programme
and report back at a subsequent meeting. The
following gentlemen were then appointed
members of the committee: Hon. J. W.
Clarke, Capt. G. S. Mac, Mr. N. Campbell, Com. Stewart, Dr. Bain, J.
Knowles, G. T. Brown, J. L. Johnson,
J. R. Milne, Capt. J. F. Murray, Capt.
Agnew, J. D. Macveety, Capt. Craig, J.
F. Bell, Graham Neill, G. E. Carter, Dr.
G. S. Davison, Capt. T. Eagles, Dr. Dr.
Jardine, Archdeacon McKay, Jas. San-
derson, W. V. Maclean, John Macdon-
ald, J. H. MacKenzie, Capt. Goodfellow, Wm. Plaxton, J. F. A.
Stall, A. L. Hilton, the Sup't. Police and
the Mayor. At a subsequent meeting
and the General Committee held a meet-
ing. Hon. Lawrence Maclean in the chair.

An Order in Council was issued com-
prising Hon. Lawrence Clarke, Col.
Spratt, T. N. Campbell, Chas. Mac and
Mayor MacArthur, who were to ap-
point sub-committees to consider the
different matters and report at an early date. Some discussion took
place on the question of establishing a
permanent memorial, such as a hospital,
and it was decided that whatever funds
remained after the celebration of the cele-
bration had been defrayed should be
left to the people to dispose of.

WEIGHTS AND MEASURES ACT.

For the information of all concerned
this week give Section 41 of the
Weights and Measures Act. After the
Act is passed, any person or his
assistant may, at any reasonable time,
without notice, enter any shop, store,
warehouse, or other place of business
over, within his division, where any com-
modity is bought, sold, exposed or kept
for sale, and examine every article or
conveyance by weight or measure, and
there examine all weights, measures,
balances, scales, and other weighing
machines, and compare and try the
same with the local standards of weight
or measure, and shall make such ex-
aminations as often as may be deemed
necessary, and shall be his duty from
time to time, and without previous notice, so as best to
enable him to carry out the provisions of
this Act, and the discovery and punish-
ment of any infractions thereof; and it
shall be his duty to attend at least once
in each month, and shall be deemed
engaged in the performance of his
duties, for the purpose of inspecting and
testing all weights, measures, balances,
scales, and other weighing machines in
his division; and he shall be also subject to regulations made

A FRIEND IN NEED.

In the last volume of his memoirs,
Lord Kamesh relates an incident which
occurred during the war after the Han-
nibal revolution of 1815.

Kamesh had fled to Widkin, and, with
companion, was in danger of being hung
by the Jacobins. The latter could not
be immediately dispatched to Lord Kamesh, begging his interven-
tion.

"I ought to go on," said he. "While we
were thinking how this could be done, a
man entered my department—a typical
Englishman—tall, dark, with a black
umbrella over his forehead, an immense umbrella
under his arm, covered with dust and
looking exceedingly weary. It could be
easily seen that he had been on a long
journey.

"Excuse me, gentlemen," said the man, "am I not late? Take a
chair."

He sat down, pushed his hat still further back, wiped the perspiration
from his forehead, and laid his umbrella
between his legs, and busied himself
with cleaning his finger nails.

"Hungington whispered to me—

"Who is that gentleman?"

"I am late, gentlemen!"

"I am late, sir; are we obliged you?"

"I have come from India, to fight for
the freedom of Hungary. It looks as if
I had come too late."

"Unfortunately, too late. Take a
chair."

"Well, the matter is settled," said Mr.
Hannibal, "and here he explained the circumstances. We
require men who will travel to London
without stopping and without sleeping,
and who will not rest until he has placed
his head in Palmerston's hands.

Will you do that?"

The brave Englishman jumped up
from his chair, reached into his coat,
and produced a letter.

"I gave it to him, he put it in his knapsack,
drove his feet down over his ears,
and wrote on the back of his hand:

"'All right, good-bye,' and he rushed out.

It took him a quarter of an hour to
hear the sound of horses' hoofs on the
street, and there he was, with a servant,
riding due west. He took advantage of
the quickest route, and did not rest until
he had put my letter in Palmerston's
hands. The latter also had the desired
effect.

I was travelling in Niagara, Canada,
when I came upon a station to allow
myself time to read the newspapers in
the direction. At the desire of the people I
went to the window, and there I saw a
visiting card. I took it and read: 'Mr.
Palmerston, Esquire.' I wrote it with
pen and ink, 'I gave Palmerston the
letter, but I do not know the name of
the man, but never heard any-
thing more of him afterwards.'"
